reviews.review_title: Nilbog, Vacation capitol of the world!
reviews.content: It is really hard to describe this "film" without using the phrases 'Holy s**t' and 'f****d up' but I will try.  By the way this review contains some spoilers.So there is a town called Nilbog where a bunch of Goblins (that's right Goblins, no trolls in this movie) pose as slacked jawed yokels and feed tourists curdled milk and oddly colored cakes.  Food so vile looking that no human would even consider eating it.  But the hapless family that this movie centers on seems to really find the Nilbog cuisine quite appealing. The food in Nilbog has two interesting properties, it makes you become a puddle of Goblin attracting green slime or it makes you become a half human, half plant (the favorite food of Goblins).  The forces behind this movie never decided which cliche was better I guess (neither). One thing is for sure, these goblins hate non-vegetable foods.  As in the General Store scene the very mention of eggs makes the store owner spit in disgust. The movie has a vile witch in it, vile due to her acting, otherwise laughable. One quote of hers shall always haunt me: "I am your neigh-bore", that is how she says it and I agree.  She takes the green colored cake for the most foolish and overdone character I've seen in years.  It is a spectacle to be seen to be believed. The family featured in this movie is a real treat, if they were in Huckleberry Finn they could be the raft because they are four planks of wood.  The most unsure, nervous actors I have ever seen.  Their eyes dart around as if begging to be saved from drowning.  Some scenes are obviously cut short due to forgotten lines.  The family is a real combo.  You have the weight lifting, bad dancer daughter who hates her boyfriend for hanging out with his boys-a, you have a Stepford Wife, a mannequin with a country drawl for the Husband and of course the son, a plucky li'l redhead who stumbles his way into saving the whole sorry lot of them with the help of a dead grandfather who talks to him and suggests molotov cocktails as a solution (among other things which must be seen to be believed). I could not believe the boyfriend of the family's daughter.  His skills were nonexistent, it was like a middle school rehearsal gone bad.  You really need to see this guy (and his boyza).  But the daughter is of course no prize either.  Her lines come out as smooth as a chainsaw cutting through asphalt.Now some quick rips: The Goblins look like sacks of potatoes with homemade masks on. The guy who stretches outside the R.V. has quite a warmup eh? The popcorn scene is coma-inducing. The townspeople are a real bunch of lookers. A Duoble Decker Bologna Sandwich!  Is this some kind of sick joke or what?This movie is recommended for the following reasons: Goblins are foolish. The movie is ridiculous. MST3k would have a field day with this dog. A good lesson on what not to do when making a film. You will laugh and laugh (in disgust)Sub-Z movies can be a real treat But watch in moderation: This thing is so bad it ripped off Manos The Hands of Fate with the "Row Row Row Your Boat" sung while driving.

Unfortunately for the robot family, their exchange family is actually actually a pack of very short cannibals who like to wear cheap latex monster masks, and who have some kind of obsession with green slime, specifically, getting their victims to eat the green slime. I think.Anyway, on their drive over -- after a truly emotional robot argument between the robot father and his robot daughter over her choice in boyfriends -- the youngest robot son thinks he sees his grandfather standing on the side of the road, and convinces the family to stop and pull over. Grandfather warns him of the monster-masked monsters lurking in their new town, and then the shrooms wear off and he turns back into a smelly, surly hobo. Then some stuff happens, and the family arrives at their destination, where, upon noticing how deserted it looks, the robot father makes the astute observation that, "country folk go to bed at this time of night", then takes advantage of the bright, mid-afternoon sun to drive the rest of the way to their vacation-home.Once there, they meet the family that will be driving to their home, and the youngest son receives a threat, which triggers another episode wherein he believes the ghost of his Grandfather has returned and is telling him to pee on everybody's dinner. Stupid robot. Shortly after this, I fell into the sweet embrace of sleep, and only awoke at the end, where the monsters and their leader -- an incomplete MtF transsexual -- are defeated by a lot of scowling, and, to be honest, I don't think the ending would have made any more sense if I'd been awake for all of it. ...Oh yes, I am leaving out the super-super twist-ending, because if you are that interested in the story, you deserve to have to sit through the whole freakin' movie, you twit.1/10, but only because there is no 0 option.

reviews.review_title: This is the Troll 2 yo' mama warned you about!

Troll 2, a time-traveling, mischief-making apparition, is from the streets.Julia-Louis Dreyfus who played the beautiful Girlcat (the sexy college professor who sees beyond Troll 2's rough exterior for the man that he is) is NOT in this movie, as it is a prequel, but there are allusions to her and the imminent intertwining of their eventual fate.See this before you see the first Troll, and then scour the internet for the massive collection of fan fiction, because you're going to have to wait until 2009 for Troll 3! Julia-Louis Dreyfus IS attached, and Brett Ratner is said to be bringing his unique and original vision to the series as both the writer AND director! See you in the theatres!

reviews.review_title: Yet another over-rated "so bad it's......" only rediscovered because of internet boredom surfing and YoutTube
reviews.content: I don't get the notoriety and the alleged "so bad it's good" fanfare of this film?OK I love bad movies. Specifically I love unintentional comedies in the Action/Martial Arts genre.Whether it is a proper Hollywood production with Swarzenegger (Commando), Van Damme (Street Fighter) Chuck Norris (The Delta Force) or some obscure undiscovered VHS gold starring ? (Deadly Prey) (Lady Terminator).Without sounding a hypocrite I discovered a good laugh by scraping the barrel with Undefeatable (check out "best fight scene ever" on YouTube) and the pant wettingly funny Samurai Cop.Most of the above films have one thing in common. Foreign film makers directing Western "actors" with hilarious consequences- odd plot quirks and really bad acting- and an abuse of film-making conventions.Avid film buffs, media studies students and fans of late night movies with 4 tins of beer tend to lap up these type of films.However there is a new sub branch fanbase of these types of films that casual fans of bad movie wince at. Anti-social YouTube reviewers (shudder), nerdy blog posters (Cinema Snob) and other friendless, weirdo basement dweller types who do video reviews that are as long as the film itself. Why? You might as well go and watch the film, download it, rent it or buy from the bargain bin at the DVD store. But what makes it worse is their odd choices of "bad movies" that just aren't funny- they're downright boring.One of these films is Troll 2. I only made it to the 48 minute mark and after pausing the film for the 4th time I switched it off. The film isn't that badly made- its a very average straight to VHS low budget horror flick. Sure the make up effects are atrocious even by late 80s, horror standards but we're all familiar with people using them in their profile pictures on public chat forums- whatever humour has been lost. As for the acting and scripting there is little in Troll 2 you didn't get in any other straight to VHS horror- waiting to be exhumed and used in "viral" Gifs, Internet humour and (excuse the pun) trolling message boards with weird stills from the film.A bit like when "The Room" came out with Tommy Wiseau. Whilst so many geek film critics thought that film was hilarious; I didn't. In my opinion that was just like the bad unsexy "erotic" made-for-TV thrillers of the early 90'sIn summary don't waste your life watching Troll 2. If you thought the infamous "Oh myyyyyyyyyy godddddddd" scene was the most hilarious thing you've ever seen a) you've lived a sheltered life b) you don't know was real bad acting is c) that was the highlight of the film's "comedy" so no need to watch any more

"Troll 2" is film that everyone should see at least once in their lives. Not because it's technically competent or well-made. Not because it features great acting or magnificent directing. Every single thing about the film is inept: the acting's awful, the director shows no skills, heck even the title is incorrect as there's no trolls in the film. And that's why you should see it.The film is one of the greatest examples of "so bad it's good" cinema. It's inept in ways that make the film hilarious. It's one of the funniest movies that I've ever seen.Easily the best scene in the film is the (in)famous "They're eating her scene" scene. The way Arnold (played by Darren Ewing) speaks during the scene is the main reason. He sounds bored at first, but when he has say "oh my God" he goes hilariously over-the-top. Making it even better, there's a fly on his forehead when he says it.Close runner-ups for best scenes include the infamous scene where Joshua (played by Michael Stephenson) gets his family to not eat the goblin by urinating on it and the end where the goblins are chowing down on Joshua's mother.

Referred to as 'the worst film of all time'? The film needs to be seen at the right time, and probably three viewings, just to fully appreciate how 'so bad it's good' it is. It is bad, real bad...but in many ways it's good. There's no doubting Troll 2 has a charm about it, it's amusing in its silliness. And it's never boring. Troll 2 could never be accused of being dull. The acting is...well...You have the grandfather (Robert Ormsby) who not only looks like Orson Welles but, in what is Ormsby's only acting performance, is good enough to match the great man. The boy too is pretty good. Around them are cast 'actors' ranging from reasonable to outright ridiculous, as if they practised acting by watching re-runs of Scooby Doo. Some 'performances' seem to have been carved out of wood, the kind you'd find in an M Night Shyamalan film, but at a much lower price. The special effects... sometimes they're OK for a low budget movie, but mostly are moments of comedy genius, like the food which seems to have been created by 5-year-olds. The real stars of the show, though, are the trolls themselves, or goblins as they're known. Some of the masks are so hilariously bad you can't help but like them...and then there's one or two in particular...well you have to see it for yourself. And see it you should, there's nothing else like it.

Throughout this whole movie my hand never strayed to my crotch not even once.Plus the characterization seemed a little thin.You know Troll backwards is Llort...so whats with nilbog?This movie has a message but it tries too hard.Don't take yourself so seriously every movie cant be an Oscar contender.This movie reeks of being released too quickly just so it could get so-called "oscar buzz".I enjoyed "Rain Man" I cried during "Mask" but come on the handicapped tear jerker has gone too far.I mean a whole family of retards is bad enough but then they move to a whole town full of tards?This movie just yells love me...love me please!I'm a masterpiece!The big budget seemed well spent and the effects still hold up well today.As a footnote last year I was traveling on business and I passed a town called retsnomdedrat,But I didn't stop because I figured the place was probably full of retarded vegetarian trolls.You live you learn.

reviews.review_title: The worst movie I have ever seen
reviews.content: I decided to watch this movie with my cousin one day. 'How bad could be it be?' I thought, expecting something on the level of MST3K movie. So it begins. An rather odd fairytale begins the movie. Something about a princess with goblins and being turned into a green pile of living vegetable, at least I think, I have blocked this movie out of my mind. So then it shows a old man talking to his Grandson, Joshua. Then the story ends and Joshua's mother comes it, and Grandpa Seth is gone. As it turns out, Grandpa Seth has been dead for 6 months and Joshua constantly sees him.So the father talks about them swapping homes with a family in the country for a couple of weeks. There is some sort of subplot with the teenage sister of Joshua having a boyfriend and him not coming with them to the home swap. So the family begins to drive, then Joshua suddenly has green goo coming from his forehead. He starts to turn into a plant and I blocked the rest out of my mind.Anyway, they arrive in the town of 'Nilbog'. There is NO subtle-ness here. As it turns out, the town is made of Goblins looking like humans. It ends with Joshua being cornered by the goblins and him pulling out a sandwich and screaming 'A double-decker bologna sandwich!' and eating it. This kills the monsters. Seriously.All in all, this is an awful, awful movie. The worst I have ever seen. EVER!

reviews.review_title: Yes this movie blew, yes whoever wrote probably did so to win a bet.
reviews.content: This movie is the equivalent of constipation--it is a slow a painful process that is only rewarded when the process is complete. The screenplay seems to be written by an incoherent vegetarian with a budget of $16.34.The plot basically revolves around vegetarian Goblins that have a knack for baking, an old woman that likes to turn people into trees, and a small boy and his dead grandpa. But wait, it gets better. To fool strangers into falling into their clutches, the Goblins name their town Nilbog (Because its such a normal sounding name, and nobody can tell that its Goblin backwards, right?). Then the Gobline, due to their high intelligence quotient, only have milk in all their stores, and they give the milk out for free (yet somehow the family still eats, the Goblins still have all their culinary supplies, and the Goblin Queen has...corn).But obvious as it is, Jonathon and his family still move to Nilbog, unperturbed by the fact that they are switching homes with a random family, the town is Goblin backwards, their children see ghosts, the place only has milk, and the Goblin Queen calls Jon's sister appetizing.Oh but wait, did I mention the Goblins can walk? Yes! They don't CHASE Jonathon, they walk after him with sticks. Intimidating, right? And when they do catch him, they pick him up and carry him five feet away, and put him down. Yes, the Goblins are also capable from moving you from Point A to Point B, so you better run! But then there are some good parts. Jon's Grandpa can turn into lightning, a guy makes out with a corn cob, Jon has a MOLATOV COCKTAIL (that is confiscated by a Goblin, and thats the end of that plan...anticlimactic...) and, dare I say it, a bologna sandwich! So basically, the bad guys only have vegetables and sticks at their disposal, despite the fact that in their human forms, they have shotguns and chainsaws. For about 10 minutes of the movie, all you see is a guy making out with corn and get covered in popcorn.This movie just sucked. I recommend going out and playing a game of Dungeons and Dragons with a four year old child with a full bladder. You will get better results that way...

Never have I given a movie more than an 8, and certainly not a 10, since a 10 implies that a movie is perfect, and I felt that a perfect movie couldn't exist. This movie made me question that assumption. This movie is a true work of art, dealing with the delicate issue of generational mental illness affliction in a Utah family in a creative way. In the movie mental illness is represented metaphorically as goblins. The movie starts out with Grandpa Seth of the Waits family, reading a story about goblins to young Joshua. Afterwards Grandpa Seth tries to convince his grandson that goblins exist, they do and Grandpa Seth is telling him. It seems as if Grandpa Seth is making an effort to pass his delusions onto his grandson, that is until his mother steps in the door and asks who Joshua is talking too, in which the chair Grandpa Seth was sitting on is shown empty. So it's not Grandpa Seth pushing his crazy on his grandson, but Joshua himself showing signs of mental illness. Diana Waits, his daughter, who herself clearly is a sufferer of some mental affliction, worries about the whole ordeal she had just witnessed, and talks about the situation with her husband George Waits. She asks George who the goblins are, unto which George scoffs. George Waits seems like the sanest at first until you realize that his idea of a vacation is exchanging houses with strangers from the country. The exchange is where the insanity really comes out, as the family must fight their demons in the form of the towns' people, which of whom they believe are cheaply costumed vegetarian goblins who want to devour them. There's a side story where the teen daughter of the Waits is having problems with her gay boyfriend, who is either using her as a beard, or since he seems mentally challenged, isn't able to understand why his girlfriend would have a problem with him sleeping with his friends. The daughter, who seems to have a type of dissociative personality disorder, stays with him even though she seems to know about this. The parents know of this and don't want Holly to hang out with this playboy son of the Coopers. He ends up going into the town the Waits are going with his friends, who he sleeps with, in his camper. One of the friends of Holly's boyfriends friends, whose name is Arnold is involved in a scene where he and a girl he had just met are caught in an old building by a crazy towns' lady, who is queen of the goblins in a poignant scene that foreshadows the ending where Joshua realizes he can't escape his madness. In this scene the girl who Arnie tried to save is caught and eaten by the goblins, and Arnie, who is turning into a tree and can't move, is forced to watch. Horrified he screams out, "They're eaten her. And then they're going to eat me. Oh my Gaaaawwwd!" This scene is best viewed in Hungarian; https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=c8PyNeSV2J8There is an anti-meat message that is pronounced through the character Creedence after Grandpa Seth gives Joshua a bologna sandwich, which he eats to defeat the goblins. Perhaps Joshua's illness is brought on by a lack of meat in his diet? So maybe it's pro-meat? Anyway this movie makes you question which is a good thing. In the end the Waits return home, and everything seems okay, until Joshua awakens to see green slime, which is what the goblins turn people into to eat, since they can't eat meat they make people one with the vegetable world. He goes into the kitchen to see the goblins on the floor eaten his mom who has turned half plant. This shows that he can't run away from his problem, and the illness that is eating his mother is going to eat him too. The kid who played Joshua was so affected that he made a documentary on the Troll 2 phenomena as an adult, revisiting some of the old cast; http://www.imdb.com/title/tt1144539/ This film is a Tour' Force! A Masterpiece! If you're only going to watch one movie during your lifetime it should be this! If you decide to watch this film, make sure there's somebody watching with you. -David Manning

reviews.review_title: If Gone with the Wind were a horror movie...
reviews.content:
...it would be this masterpiece, a magnum opus of terror. The director enthralls the audience with scenes of wit, humor, fright, and heart.
Truly it is a tale of the stages of grief, as our protagonist, young Joshua, pines for his departed Grandpapa Seth. He vacillates from denial to acceptance, and every stage in between, with the aplomb of a Sixth Sense Haley Joel Osment.
It is also a cautionary tale to warn us of the evils of vegetarianism. Surely those who do not consume meat are actually chlorophyll-obsessed goblins. There is no other alternative.
It also is a precursor to David Fincher's top-notch film Se7en, who surely took inspiration from Troll 2 when examining our basest human nature and penchant for sin. Gluttony and lust reign supreme in this film, with a scene of copulation and a rather phallic corn cob that reminds us all that too much of a good thing (even light, low calorie popcorn!) leads to evil.
Watch this movie. Analyze this cinematic phenomenon. Afterwards, you'll never need to watch another film ever again. Or maybe you just won't want to.

The worst acting in the movie, let me think. It's a tossup between the store owner and the sister. I do think the sister tops the cake. "WHOD WANNA EAT CHA LITTLE BROTHER?" LMAO! reviews.review_title: This is diabolical, but you'll love every minute.
reviews.content: Wow. Where do I start with this film? The acting, the costumes, the dialogue, the camera work, the cast itself? It's all really, really dire. But here's the thing - it is so bad it's possibly the funniest film I've ever seen. The plot of the film is very weak. I've never seen Troll so I can't compare the two, but I'll be pretty sure it won't involve people turning into a cabbage.Another thing to love about this film is the acting throughout. At school we put on a better acted performance. That was in the Nativity play when I was four. At least at that age we didn't know we were bad actors (I was one of the Three Wise Men, which is a vaguely ironic role for a four year old boy). These guys have no excuses. The daughter makes out that she's reading from cue cards all the time.The best thing about the film is the costumes of the goblins themselves. Oh yeah, by the way, it's about goblins not trolls. Not one troll in the movie. If ever there was a case of false advertising, this'd be it. Not that I was particularly craving some troll action. Anyway, back to the costumes. Most of the goblins looks the same - paper bag skin and joke shop mask accessories but there is one which doesn't look like the rest and is possibly an extra from the Muppet Show. Just so you know which one I'm on about, it appears in the car on the journey to Nilbog.Just to give you an idea of how bad this film is, here's a line from the father of the family: "I'm tightening my belt one loop so I don't feel hunger pains and your mother and sister will have to do the same." This is the quintessential "so bad it's good" movie. The first thing you need to know about Troll 2, to adjust your expectations, is that it contains not a single troll. If that seems like a pretty big problem for a film called Troll 2, then you haven't seen anything yet. This movie contains such fantastical scenes as... as... a helpful ghost stopping time so that a kid can jump onto a dinner table and pee all over his family's food, which is naturally the only sane way to prevent them from eating a substance that would otherwise turn them all into goblin snacks (oh, yes, there are goblins in Troll 2, just no trolls). In another scene, the villainous witch who rules the goblins becomes a sexy femme fatale and seduces a young man in his trailer, brandishing what I can only describe as a corn-on-the-cob dildo. After the lad falls under the witch's spell, so to speak, the two frolic on his bed "eating" the phallic corn until, at the climactic moment, popcorn erupts out of thin air, shooting everywhere and covering them. This is some pretty strong visual allegory for a PG 13 rated release! The narrative purpose of the scene, though, like much in Troll 2, is unclear, given that after the witch leaves the lad he seems perfectly fine and none the worse for his experience. Others victims are not so lucky, finding themselves turned into edible vegetation for goblins to feast upon. Some of the acting in Troll 2 vies with the best that Tommy Wiseau's The Room or Neil Breen's Fateful Findings has to offer. I would say that Troll 2 is unintentionally hilarious, but I'm not so confident in offering an opinion on what the filmmakers intended when making Troll 2. What I can say is that, although Troll 2 is "bad" on a whole different level from most of its competitors, I unironically love it.

From producer Joe D'Amato, the man who brought you "Porno Holocaust" and "The Erotic Nights of Aladdin" brings you "Troll 2." D'Amato actually billed himself as David Hills since he name has been forever associated with cheap and poorly made Italian productions. This film actually has no connection to the Charles Band film "Troll" and was originally written as titled "Goblin." Trolls are never actually mentioned in the film. This story is about the small town of Nilbog where the inhabitants are all acting quite strange and doing their best to get visitors to it their strange green food and drinks, which then turn them into on of their zombified townsfolk who try to get others to join them in their green food eating ways. Supposedly the director and his co-screenwriter wife wrote this in reaction to too many of their friends becoming vegetarians. But this film is one that has now deservedly earned a cult following in a "Plan 9 From Outer Space" so-bad-it's-good kind of way. Many of the film's actors showed up for auditions to play extras but ended up being cast in lead roles. The director an his co-screenwriter wife did not speak English well and there screenplay was written in that same broken English, but to add to the film's ridiculousness, they forbade actors from altering their grammatically incorrect and nonsensical dialogue. It's an embarrassingly awful and ineptly made film to be sure, but that's wherein it's entertainment value lies.

This pathetic excuse for a film begins with a fat old man named "Grandpa Seth" narrating a pointless story to his grandson Jonathan. According to "legend", some guy with a silly hat ran through the woods once, attempting to escape the clutches of some evil goblins who were undoubtedly attempting to catch and hit him with their fake plastic masks. The idiot guy with the hat eventually falls down and is picked up by a comically dorky woman who feeds him magical green porridge. This pastel green soup makes him sweat Cascade dishwashing detergent and turns him into "half man, half plant", which I like to call a "mlant." He is then supposedly eaten by the goblins, but I'm not exactly sure how this happens because the prop guy didn't cut the holes for their mouths big enough to get anything larger than a Tic-Tac through. Maybe when "Goblin Mask v2.0" is created, they'll be able to physically put something in their tiny mouths other than the director's minuscule penis.

The back-story-story is then interrupted when Jonathan's mom walks into the room and Grandpa Seth instantly disappears. According to the movie, this is because Seth has been dead for half a year. Mom and dad begin to talk about how excited they are to go to the town of "Nilbog", where they're swapping houses with a farm family. 

Yes, "Nilbog". The town is named NILBOG. Do you get it? Are you impressed with the extreme degree of cleverness and creativity the "writers" exhibited when brainstorming this plot in their respective jail cells? I won't even go into detail with how intensely stupid the idea of swapping houses with a random farming family in the woods is, but then again, this movie seems to have been filmed in some sort of alternate universe where aliens dress up and try to act like how they guess human beings would. Nobody in this film reacts in any explicable sense to the events that occur around them. It's almost as if they wrote down six basic human emotions on a piece of paper and rolled a die every scene to determine which one they would attempt to portray.

Anyway, the family of Jonathan, Michael, Diana, and Holly heads out to the wonderful and wacky town of NILBOG (NILBOG!!!) and begins to get in an argument in their minivan on the way there. The daughter and father fight about her boyfriend, who the father believes is a "rotten good-for-nothing" just because the kid's really stupid and hangs out with his homosexual friends all day. To break up the tension and bickering, the mom steps in and requests Jonathan to "sing that song I like so much." The song, "Row, Row, Row Your Boat" was obviously too technical and confusing for the mother to recall the name of, but that still doesn't quite explain why she liked it "so much." I would guess it's because she's an idiot, but I've been wrong before.

The family finally pulls into NILBOG (haha, NILBOG!), a town full of farmers who participate in a constant foam hat conventions, and meets the antisocial weirdos who they're swapping houses with. In a terribly scary moment of foreshadowing, the little farmer boy tosses a baseball to Jonathan which reads "Eat up before we eat you". Ooh, scary! Jonathan's family enters the house and are overjoyed to find a table full of prop food which doesn't look even remotely like anything anybody reasonably intelligent would consume. There's green biscuits, pitchers full of bright red and green liquid, and corn on the cob with green paste smeared all over it. So, being the braindead morons they are, Michael, Diana, and Holly all immediately dig in and prepare to shovel the filth down their throats. Before they can cram a single moldy biscuit into their stomachs, Grandpa Seth appears in a mysterious and shocking way (he knocks at the window). He explains to Jonathan that he has to stop his family from eating any of the food because it will turn them into goblins, or even worse, legitimate actors. Jonathan gets Grandpa Seth to stop time for 30 seconds (I really can't explain how he does it, I guess it's a perk you get for being dead) and does the only rational thing he can do to stop them from eating the food;he pees all over it. I'm not kidding. Once time resumes again, Michael takes Jonathan to his room and gives him a stern lecture that contains the phrase "you can't piss on hospitality", which is one of those lessons that you just can't learn on the mean streets of Nilbog.

Holly's boyfriend and his cretin pals show up in their mobile home and park it in the woods, undoubtedly so the rest of the residents of Nilbog won't be awakened by their lusty cries of ecstasy during the night. One of the friends named Arnold goes outside the camper to smoke, sees a pretty girl running through the woods, starts chasing her, and gets a spear thrown into him by some marauding goblins. Arnold and the girl decide the best place for them to hide from the goblins would a nearby ominous, gothic, scary house, so they go in and get molested by a Druid lady. The woman playing the Druid is one of the most embarrassing examples of overacting in the history of modern film. She stretches out every vowel to approximately four hours in length, wildly gesticulates as if she were petting electric dogs, and forces her eyes open to the point of looking as if dinner plates were lodged in her forehead. She offers her guests a couple mugs full of dry ice and lime Jello, which they drink. This causes the girl to turn into a lump of slime and Arnold to transform in a tree (a tree that sweats dishwashing detergent). Drew, another one of the fools in the trailer, decides to run to town and get some milk. Oh, the wild and crazy kids these days, what will they do next? On the way to the general store, Drew is given a ride by Sheriff Freak, the law authority of Nilbog. Sheriff Freak (that's really his name, I swear) gives the kid a green sandwich and he immediately eats. The kid is dropped off by the sheriff, buys some milk, and then runs into the Druid's house to hang out with his buddy Arnold, who is still a mlant. I think he ends up being killed or something, I don't remember. It's not very crucial to the plot, all the kids were just cannon fodder anyway.

Jonathan stumbles upon the evil goblin church, which is actually the director's unfurnished basement, and gets captured by them (the goblins, not the director). They try to make him eat evil Nilbog ice cream, but his dad shows up and scares them away by threatening to call their parents and tell them that their kids are dressing up in goblin costumes and making lame movies when they should be studying for school. Grandpa Seth, who took time out of his busy schedule of "being dead", shows up and hands Jonathan a Molotov cocktail so he can blow up the goblins, which surround his family and chase them into their house. Well, they don't really chase them, they just stand in place while the family runs away. The goblins surround the house (by standing in place) and throw bags of sandwiches onto the porch, which I assume is how goblins traditionally attack their enemies. There's a scene placed in the movie around this point which involves some kid and the Druid eating corn together (which explodes and turns into popcorn), but I'm not going to bring it up because even mentioning it makes my brain hemorrhage. Eventually Jonathan and his family hold a seance to summon the spirit of dead ol' Grandpa Seth, and Jonathan mysteriously appears in the Druid's house. I don't know how, he just teleports there or something. He and Grandpa Seth attempt to kill the entire goblin race by touching the "Stonehenge Magic Stone" (I'm not making that name up), but it doesn't work. I though it might be more effective if they just pushed the damn foam rock over onto the Druid lady, but apparently that wasn't a valid option. So this is about a family that goes on a vacation for the month to Nilbog, participating in some household exchange program (...?), only to find all of the inhabitants of the town are all goblins in disguise, trying to trick them into eating vegetables so as to turn them into half-plants in order to eat them.  I finally took the time to watch one of the most infamously bad movies ever made, and let me tell you, I had a great time.  Don't be put off with how I am rating it, as I am grading it purely from a filmmaking standpoint; it is unintentionally hilarious to the core.  The thing about making a good bad movie is that you can't set out to make a bad movie; if you wink too hard at your audience, the joke ceases to be funny, and then you end up with something like Machete.  You have to have a madman sitting in the director's chair and let it happen naturally, and that's how you wind up with something like Troll 2 or The Room.  Everything about this is fun if you watch it in the right atmosphere, from the clunky exposition to the wooden performances, from the laugh-worthy troll masks and make-up to the drunkenly penned dialogue, there is nothing here that doesn't fail hard. Rivaling Tommy Wiseau's "The Room" for the best unintentional comedy ever comes Troll 2, a horrendously inept trainwreck of a movie that is as fascinating as it is bad. There's really not much that I can say that hasn't been said already, but here's a start:

The acting isn't nearly as consistently bad as The Room's, but certain key moments stand out when they become a spectacle of hilarity (see: "They're eating her...and now they're going to eat me! OH MY GOOOOOOOOOD!"). The storytelling is tremendously weak, and showcases tremendously obvious foreshadowing that any sane person could see. The writing is just plain awful, featuring lines such as "Nilgob! It's goblin spelled backwards!" and the immortal "You can't piss on hospitality!" And the plot? Oh yeah, don't even get me started. This is a movie about goblins (despite being called Troll 2) that feed people food that makes them sweat/bleed chlorophyll and turns them into half-plant, half-human hybrids, "the goblins' favorite food". Yeah. Not even joking. 

What does elevate this movie to "so-bad-it's-good" status are any of the scenes that involve Grandpa Seth or the dad, played by Robery Ormsby and George Hardy, respectively. It's never really explained if Grandpa Seth is a figment of the kids imagination or not, and that just adds to the comedic factor in the movie. Also noteworthy is the horrifyingly creepy shopkeeper, who, if you've watched the documentary based on this film, "Best Worst Movie", was actually in a mental institution at the time of filming. Explains quite a bit.

If there's one person to blame for the astoundingly bad quality of this film, it's Italian director Claudio Fragrasso. If you look up some of the backstory to this film, you'll learn that he thought he knew more about American teenagers than the actual cast and crew, and also thought that he was pretty much the best director of all time. It's pretty clear that he had no clue what he was doing or what constitutes a good movie. 

Though Troll 2 isn't nearly as hilariously bad as other unintentional comedies (see: The Room), you can find a lot to have fun with in this movie, even if sometimes it is just boring. I personally didn't think that this film was as notoriously bad as its reputation suggests, but there's still a lot to enjoy when watching Troll 2.

There's only one reason Troll 2 stands out in the vast sea of bad movies I've seen: it was never meant to be bad at all. Sure, it was destined for cinema hell from the start. Sure, the cast had no experience. Sure, the budget could, at best, buy me a coffee table from Ikea. But despite all that, you get a sense watching this movie that everyone involved really, really wanted to make a good movie. I'm not saying that Troll 2 is worth seeing. But I give it an E for effort.

rt_summary: When young Joshua (Michael Stephenson) learns that he will be going on vacation with his family to a small town called Nilbog, he protests adamantly. He is warned by the spirit of his deceased grandfather that goblins populate the town. His parents, Michael (George Hardy) and Diana (Margo Prey), dismiss his apprehensions, but soon learn to appreciate their son's warnings. Guided by his grandfather's ghost, will Joshua and his family stand a chance in fighting off these evil beings?
meta_summary: A vacationing family discovers that the entire town they're visiting is inhabited by goblins, disguised as humans, who plan to eat them.
